data.text:
Well, I hadnâ€™t planned to write an extra â€œHorror Videogames Seriesâ€ article and I also often tend to avoid internet arguments too. Not to mention that, because of things like the likely system requirements for it on PC, the likely cost of it and my almost decade-long policy of not buying or playing games with online DRM (yes, even Steam), Iâ€™m probably not going to be playing the upcoming remake of â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) any time soonâ€¦.

This article may contain SPOILERS and DARK SUBJECT MATTER.

Still, I was surprised to see that there was a bit of an online fuss about the redesigned version of Angela in the trailers. Leaving aside how the new version of the character is apparently based on the original early 2000s concept artistâ€™s sketches or how she is canonically meant to be an older teenager, a lot of the criticism seemed to focus on her visual design.

Some of the more crass video thumbnails Iâ€™ve seen seem to criticise the fact that she doesnâ€™t look â€œglamourousâ€ or â€œbeautifulâ€ or anything like that. And I have to wonder if the people criticising her appearance have actually paid attention to the story of the original game.

Without going into too many horrific details â€“ most of which are mercifully only implied â€“ sheâ€™s a deeply depressed character who has suffered some extremely terrible things and then acted in self-defence. And her new character design accurately reflects this. Sheâ€™s someone who doesnâ€™t have a huge amount of energy, probably doesnâ€™t have much money and is plagued with bad memories and â€“ arguably unfair â€“ guilt.

So, yes, she probably isnâ€™t going to have the energy or resources to wear lots of make-up, shape her eyebrows or have lots of fashionable outfits. Also, given that the game is set in a rural area over two decades ago (unless theyâ€™ve updated the setting) then, although the people who hurt her are solely responsible for their actions, it isnâ€™t impossible that Angela also believes outdated ideas about â€œnot attracting attentionâ€ as well.

This isnâ€™t the designers being â€œwokeâ€, itâ€™s just good visual storytelling. Itâ€™s using visual design as one of many forms of subtle characterisation. It also means that Bloober Team have actually studied the original game as well. And, make no mistake, virtually every element of the original â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) was a carefully-chosen creative decision.

For example, whilst the original game does include a glamourous and beautiful character â€“ Maria â€“ sheâ€™s a paranormal apparition who reflects the person that the main character â€“ James â€“ wanted his wife, Mary, to be. And, in some editions of the original game, thereâ€™s also a brilliantly eerie side-game called â€œBorn From A Wishâ€ where Maria grapples with the fact that sheâ€™s literally just a ghost designed to reflect someone elseâ€™s desires.

(On a side-note: As for Mariaâ€™s redesigned costume in the trailers, whilst I can understand some of the criticisms, I think that the designers were just going for the same idea but in a more subtle and/or timeless way. Mariaâ€™s new outfit still looks more glamourous than Maryâ€™s, but in more of an â€œexpensive designer clothesâ€ way.

Plus, as iconic as Mariaâ€™s original outfit is, it is unmistakably â€œlate 1990s/early 2000sâ€. And her new outfit looks like it could have come from any time period between about the mid-late 1960s to the present day. So, this could be a way to make the game more timeless whilst getting the same general idea across.)

The original â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) was a genuinely mature game, an intelligent work of art with lots of psychological depth. And, as a side-effect, the characters in it are a lot more realistic than the stylised characters found in some other games of the time. This was also a â€œmatureâ€ game which â€“ unusually for the time â€“ was aimed at a more general older audience as well.

Yes, unless you grew up in the 2000s and were a fan of survival horror games back then, it can be difficult to â€“ legally â€“ play the original game these days. Greedy collectors and/or re-sellers have driven up second-hand prices and the 2012 attempt at a remaster didnâ€™t go well. So, I can understand some of the critics just not understanding the original game (although there are no shortage of websites and videos explaining it).

And, whilst there probably are valid criticisms to be made of the trailers â€“ such as the generic modern â€œover the shoulderâ€ camera, the unfinished-looking UI design etcâ€¦ â€“ the more realistic visual storytelling in the new version of Angela probably isnâ€™t one of them. And, if they released a DRM-free edition of the remake, optimised for really low-spec PCs and costing about Â£15-20, then Iâ€™d probably still buy and play it in a heartbeat.

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”-

Anyway, I hope that this was interesting ğŸ™‚

Well, it has been absolutely ages since I last wrote a stand-alone â€œHorror Videogames Seriesâ€ article, and I thought that Iâ€™d look at the interesting connections between the original â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) and some types of â€œNew Thoughtâ€ spirituality today. I think that I alluded to this topic in at least one older article from the series, but I thought it was worth taking a closer look.

Other people have possibly mentioned this before but â€“ given that the overlap between â€œedgy horror videogame fansâ€ and â€œcheerful new age manifestorsâ€ is probably relatively small â€“ perhaps not.

This article will contain MAJOR PLOT SPOILERS for â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001). And, because of this, it will also contain DISTURBING SUBJECT MATTER too.

If you havenâ€™t heard of â€œNew Thoughtâ€ spirituality, it covers a range of beliefs but Iâ€™ll be focusing on the most popular element of it these days â€“ namely the concept that your experience of reality is a reflection of your beliefs/state of being/emotions/thoughts etcâ€¦.

Of course, this concept has much older roots than 19th/20th century mysticism. Elements of it can be found in everything from the Buddhist and/or Hindu concept of â€œkarmaâ€ to some passages from the Christian Bible (such as Galatians 6:7: â€œBe not deceived; God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reapâ€).

Still, the idea is popular today because of the concept of â€œmanifestationâ€. There are two main popular interpretations of this. The most common one â€“ taught by people like Rhonda Byrne and Abraham-Hicks â€“ is the â€œLaw Of Attractionâ€. This is idea that everything â€“ especially emotion and thought â€“ has a â€œvibrationâ€ and that an external god or â€œsourceâ€ will give you what you desire if your â€œvibrationâ€ matches with it for long enough. If you feel like you already have it.

A slightly less popular â€“ but Iâ€™d argue much more interesting â€“ interpretation is the â€œLaw Of Assumptionâ€ taught by the 20th century mystic Neville Goddard (1905-1972). Goddard taught that consciousness itself â€“ or awareness of being â€“ is divine and that â€œmanifestationâ€ happens because reality itself is a reflection of consciousness.

In this belief system â€“ which also has some similarities with pantheism and/or solipsism (depending on how you look at it) â€“ your first-person perspective experience of reality is a reflection of your beliefs about it and your â€œstateâ€. This is a term referring to everything from how you see yourself to the person you are being in any given moment. If you change who you are being or what you realistically believe, then â€“ according to Goddard â€“ your reality will alter itself correspondingly.

But what does any of this have to do with â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001)?

In short, Iâ€™d argue that â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) is an exploration of the â€œdark sideâ€ of this concept. It tells the story of a mourning widower called James Sunderland who â€“ seemingly out of nowhere â€“ receives a letter from his former wife, Mary, asking him to visit her in the resort town of â€œSilent Hillâ€. Even though he is uncertain, he goes there anyway. The town is shrouded with ominous fog and filled with hideous monsters.

James also meets an assortment of troubled characters, including a woman called Maria who is a â€œsimilar, but differentâ€ version of Mary, before he is eventually pushed to acknowledge the truth behind Maryâ€™s death and his own feelings of guilt about it. Whilst he deliberately caused it, the game leaves his motivations for this slightly ambiguous â€“ with it either being a merciful form of euthanasia or a murder motivated by his despair about her illness.

This psychological horror/survival horror game from over two decades ago is widely regarded as one of the best horror games ever made, thanks to its well-written characters, memorable atmosphere, excellent story and the sheer level of attention to detail throughout the game. The original game can be a bit difficult to find these days (with second-hand PS2/Xbox/PC copies sometimes being rather pricey) but there is apparently a modern remake of it being prepared by another studio called Bloober Team at the moment.

Anyway, one of the main themes of the game is that the town of Silent Hill reflects Jamesâ€™ psyche. There are a ton of small details in the game which play into this â€“ whether it is how Mariaâ€™s more free-spirited and seductive character design hints that she is the person James wanted Mary to be. Whether it is how the monster designs reflect various themes in Jamesâ€™ psyche (eg: judgement/execution, repressed lust, medical settings etc...).

Whether it is how the levels reflect Jamesâ€™ life story, with the game going from an apartment block to a hospital to a history museum/prison to the hotel he remembers visiting with Mary. Whether this is how mirrors are a recurring motif in the game â€“ with the story beginning with James staring at himself in a mirror, and a disturbing scene where another character called Angela reclines despondently beside a giant mirror whilst holding a knife. Whether it is how the gameâ€™s muted colour palette reflects Jamesâ€™ feelings of depression. Even the gameâ€™s other characters â€“ except Maria and possibly a child called Laura â€“ are also shown to experience worlds which reflect their horrible pasts.

The most chilling and tragic example of this is probably Angela, a young woman who is implied to have suffered horrible abuse at the hands of her family and then murdered them in retaliation. In her final scene in the game, we see the town from her perspective. Everything is on fire, hinting that this is how she got revenge. Before she walks away from James, she also points out that â€œFor me itâ€™s always like thisâ€œ, implying that her world is a reflection of her worst memories.

The theme of a reflective world runs throughout the entire game and, although it may have been influenced by other belief systems than â€œNew Thoughtâ€ spirituality (given the time and context the game was made in, Iâ€™d argue that Buddhist/Hindu â€œkarmaâ€, Western psychology and/or possibly elements of Christianity might have been a larger influence on a game made in early 2000s Japan), itâ€™s impossible not to notice the similarities if youâ€™ve studied anything â€œNew Thoughtâ€-related.

â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) is a really interesting game because it â€“ perhaps inadvertently â€“ shows the â€œdark sideâ€ of a philosophy that often has a very cheerful public image, one filled with pastel-coloured social media posts and â€œinspirationalâ€ quotes about manifesting money or romantic relationships. Yet, if you read into the topic, then any serious texts about it (eg: Goddard, Hicks etc...) will often point out that it is a completely neutral principle. That it reflects bad things as well as good things. And â€œSilent Hill 2â€ is, on a symbolic/thematic level, perhaps a cautionary tale about what can go wrongâ€¦

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€“

Anyway, I hope that this was interesting ğŸ™‚

Well, I hadnâ€™t planned to write another stand-alone â€œHorror Videogames Seriesâ€ article this month, but I had to. And, yes, this one will be something of a short and enthusiastic sleep-deprived ramble too. I seem to be writing articles whilst tired a lot recentlyâ€¦

Still, I had to write this article because, back in mid-late January, I happened to see an â€œInk Ribbonâ€ video where Kai Morgan looks at an old copy of Electronic Games Monthly from October 2001 (more likely September 2001 in reality, since magazines usually printed the date a month in advance. Still donâ€™t know why...).

SPOILERS ahoy for anything â€œSilent Hillâ€ or Dario Argento related!

One thing in the video seriously caught my attention. If you pause the video at 18:30, you can see a close-up of part of the preview article about the original version of â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001), where the journalists point out that the game was inspired by classic 1960s/70s Italian Giallo horror/crime films.

They then point out that Akihiro Imamura, the gameâ€™s producer, considers Dario Argentoâ€™s legendary 1977 art-horror masterpiece â€œSuspiriaâ€ to be the scariest horror film he has ever seen (And I believe him! The very first time I tried to watch â€œSuspiriaâ€, I could only make it half an hour into the film before I fled in frightâ€¦). And, yes, the date in the magazine article was an error â€“ Suspiria was released in 1977, not 1976.

Anyway, as someone who has literally written an entire article about how â€œSuspiriaâ€ has influenced horror games, Iâ€™m genuinely surprised that I didnâ€™t spot this. I mean, I got that the random red lighting in one of the hospital rooms in â€œSilent Hill 3â€ (2003) was possibly influenced by the film â€“ and that the plot/characters/themes in â€œSilent Hill 3â€, in turn, probably influenced Luca Guadagninoâ€™s 2018 remake of â€œSuspiriaâ€ â€“ but I never thought about â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) in this way until now. It actually sort of makes sense.

Yes, the muted grey aesthetic of the game â€“ its almost in black & white â€“ is about as far as you can get from the vivid psychedelic nightmare that is â€œSuspiriaâ€ (1977), but the almost dream-like style of the game is actually very close to classic Dario Argento films. Seriously, one of the defining features of classic Dario Argento horror films is that they can often include all sorts of bizarre and surreal elements that are purely there for the sake of scariness. Likewise, quite a few of Argentoâ€™s horror films â€“ such as â€œPhenomenaâ€ (1985) and â€œOperaâ€ (1987) â€“ include bizarre and random plot twists designed to shock the audience.

Ok, in some ways, â€œSilent Hill 2â€ is the exact opposite of this too. The gameâ€™s plot is meticulously constructed, with all sorts of clever foreshadowing and stuff. Even if the premise of â€œA haunted town that shapes itself around your worst memoriesâ€ is a little bizarre. Yet, there is still a lot of random side-stuff that is there to add an ominous atmosphere to the game. Whether it is the disturbing stories of the other lost souls who are trapped in the town (eg: Angela and Eddie) or even stuff like the â€œThere was a hole here...â€ graffiti on the shop window or the random mannequin wearing Maryâ€™s clothes etcâ€¦ Seriously, itâ€™s more subtle than a Dario Argento film, but itâ€™s a similar technique.

Of course, as the magazine article points out, classic Italian horror movies were only one of several influences on â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) but Iâ€™m still astonished that I didnâ€™t spot it. But, yes, some of the weirder elements of the game â€“ and perhaps some subtle elements of its atmosphere â€“ could well have been influenced by old Dario Argento, Lucio Fulci etc.. films. Possibly. I mean, I originally tried to draw comparisons between the game and Argentoâ€™s 1996 film â€œThe Stendhal Syndromeâ€, but it seemed like a bit of a stretch (eg: a female character who exists in two versions, someone not realising that they are a killer etc..).

Weirdly though, one way that â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) is different from â€œSuspiriaâ€ (1977) is its dialogue and voice-acting. Because â€œSuspiriaâ€ (1977) was originally filmed in several languages, each actor spoke their own language and then the film was dubbed afterwards, the dialogue often sounds a bit like the sort of â€œcorny voice-actingâ€ youâ€™d expect from an old survival horror game. Yet, â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) was perhaps the first game in the genre to actually put a bit more effort and nuance into its voice-actingâ€¦

I donâ€™t know what the point of this article is, I just find it astonishing that one of the best horror films ever made could have had an influence â€“ albeit a slightly subtle and difficult to see one â€“ on what is widely regarded as one of the best horror videogames ever made. Seriously, the original â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) is over twenty years old and you can still learn new stuff about itâ€¦

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”-

Anyway, I hope that this was interesting ğŸ™‚

Well, for this article in my series about horror videogames, I thought that Iâ€™d talk briefly about how horror games can use location design to set an emotional tone. To give you examples of this, Iâ€™ll be taking a look at two of the most well-designed survival horror games ever made â€“ I am, of course, talking about â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) and the 2002 remake of â€œResident Evilâ€.

The main emotional tone that â€œSilent Hill 2â€ tries to set is one of bleak loneliness and melancholy sorrow. Although a host of different things like music, writing/dialogue, character design etcâ€¦ go into creating this emotional tone, a lot of it also comes from the way that the gameâ€™s locations are designed.

In short, thereâ€™s relatively little detail and lots of open space. Youâ€™ll be spending a lot of time just walking or running through â€œemptyâ€ locations. Even the gameâ€™s â€œclaustrophobicâ€ indoor levels often feature bare walls and extended corridors â€“ and most of the doors you see cannot be opened. The colour palette of all of these locations is deliberately muted too, often just being a desaturated palette of grey, green and brown. It is deliberately designed to be â€“ dare I say it â€“ boring.

Seriously, this entire article was inspired by the fact that I spent about an hour re-playing part of â€œSilent Hill 2â€ and at least half of that time was just spent running along lengthy corridors, wide roads and almost-endless staircases. Yet, far from being a flaw, this â€œboredomâ€ is essential to the game. Not only does it give the player time to soak in the coldly bleak minimalism of many locations, but it helps to hammer home just how alone the main character is. The locations are huge, and the main character is tiny by comparison.

These long empty corridors and large wide-open outdoor areas also deliberately slow down the pacing of the gameplay, making the relatively few encounters with weak monsters feel genuinely dramatic and scary too. And, even if you hold down the â€œrunâ€ button, then the vast emptiness of many areas still comes across surprisingly wellâ€¦ given that they are large enough to still take a while to traverse when running as fast as possible. It feels lonely and emptyâ€¦ which is exactly the mood that the game is trying to evoke in the player.

One of the defining things about the â€œSilent Hillâ€ series is minimalism and/or understatement. These are games that will often imply things or leave stuff to the playerâ€™s imagination. These are games that can make something as basic as radio static sound genuinely frightening just from the context it is used in. These are games where the settings often look like they have been abandoned or stripped of all human life. And the large empty spaces and long corridors in â€œSilent Hill 2â€ play into this philosophy absolutely perfectly and use it to evoke a depressing feeling of emptiness and loss.

In contrast, the 2002 remake of â€œResident Evilâ€ tries to set a tense and suspenseful emotional tone. Although it also does this using numerous other methods like placing strict limitations on the player, using delayed jump scares, including monsters with different movement speeds etcâ€¦ the location designs in this game play a large role in setting this mood too.

Most of the game takes place in contained, claustrophobic locations. These locations have a density to them that is literally the polar opposite of â€œSilent Hill 2â€. Most of the corridors in this game are relatively short and filled with doors that not only can be opened but often must be opened at some point. Even the gameâ€™s outdoor areas are relatively small, tightly-contained locations with little in the way of free-roaming exploration on offer to the player. Its a cramped and confining game worldâ€¦ with less room to run away from monsters!

Instead of evoking a bleak mood through cold soulless minimalism, the 2002 remake of â€œResident Evilâ€ takes the opposite approach. Many of the locations in this game are designed to overwhelm the player with ornate complex detail. Even the more â€œutilitarianâ€ areas later in the game are often lavishly lit and filled with all sorts of dramatic background details. Virtually every frame of this game is a beautiful painting. And all of this visual splendour is designed to be subtly overwhelming â€“ further adding to the gameâ€™s â€œout of your depthâ€ feeling of tense suspense.

Even the gameâ€™s colour palette is designed to be slightly dramatic â€“ with many locations using almost subliminal complementary colour pairs. Blue/orange (or muted brown and bluish light) and red/green (eg: deep red/brown and pale green) seem to be the most common. Some areas even subtly play against the playerâ€™s expectations in order to keep them on their guard, such as a red-walled room you can findâ€¦ which is perfectly safe and free from monsters.

The lighting in this game is also bold and dramatic, filled with ominous contrasts between light and darkness. The claustrophobic mansion that most of the game takes place in really does look like a creepy old haunted mansion (albeit with zombies instead of ghosts). And this classic horror movie setting really helps to create a feeling of tension and suspense because of all of the memories of actual horror movies that it evokes.

So, yes, something as basic as location design can have a huge effect on the emotional tone of a horror game. Whether it is the lonely corridors and eerie emptiness of â€œSilent Hill 2â€ or the dense, tense and claustrophobic mansion in the â€œResident Evilâ€ remake, these places have been specifically designed to set a particular mood in numerous subtle ways.

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€“

Anyway, I hope that this was interesting ğŸ™‚

Well, for this article in my series about horror videogames, I thought that Iâ€™d take another look at both â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) and â€œSilent Hill 4â€ (2004). This is mostly because the four classic â€œSilent Hillâ€ games can be divided into two mini-series. The odd-numbered games tell a continuous story (albeit with a time gap between each game), and the even-numbered games tell separate â€“ but connected â€“ stories.

Before I go any further, I should warn you that this article will contain SPOILERS.

Although I personally prefer the general style and atmosphere of the odd-numbered games (especially â€œSilent Hill 3â€ (2003)), thereâ€™s no denying that the even-numbered games are the scariest classic games in the series. But, why?

Well, I think a lot of it is to do with their themes and visual style. Unlike the more overtly paranormal and occult events of the first and third games, the second and fourth games in the series are much more heavily grounded in real-life horrors. They do include paranormal elements, but the main focus is on more realistic horrors. Not only do these two games include some seriously heavy themes (eg: loneliness, murder, terminal illness, bereavement etc...), but there is also an even stronger emphasis on psychological horror in these two games too. These are games about self-loathing, claustrophobia, emotional trauma etcâ€¦

A lot of this also has to do with the scale of the stories being told. Both the first and third games tell a larger-scale story with strong cosmic horror elements. On the other hand, the stories of the second and fourth games in the series are a lot more small-scale. Not only are they separate stories, with only vague connections to each other, but they are also heavily focused on a small number of characters too. Not only does this small-scale focus add a lot more intensity to the stories of these games, but their self-contained nature also means that they player wonâ€™t know what to expect when they play one of these games for the first time either.

Yes, â€œSilent Hill 4â€ does include some occult horror elements â€“ but even these seem to be much smaller in scale than those found in the first and third games. Instead of grand magical plots involving ancient gods and nightmarish apocalypses, the villain of the fourth game just wants toâ€¦ haunt the main characterâ€™s flat. The evil things he does just to achieve this â€œsmallâ€ goal are one of the things that makes this game surprisingly creepy.

Not only that, the visual style of the even-numbered games in the series is slightly more mundane and muted than the one found in the odd-numbered games. Everything in these two games just seems a bit more grey, cold and desaturated when compared to the vivid orange rust-covered nightmares found in the first and third games. This difference is reasonably subtle most of the time, with all four games having a strong emphasis on gloomy visual bleakness, but the overall palette and visual mood of the first and third games just seems a tiny bitâ€¦ warmerâ€¦ than the second or fourth games.

There is also more emotional warmth in the first and third games in the series too. The protagonists of these two games are father and daughter and, although their lives are tragic, we still get to directly see some very brief hints of the happier times that they spend together (such as the alternate intro to the first game showing Harry and Cybil holding baby Heather, or Heatherâ€™s phone call to Harry at the beginning of the third game).

Likewise, in the first game, Harry meets at least one or two friendly characters (such as Cybil). In the third game, Heather will sometimes make amusingly sarcastic observations when you look at things. When Heather has to do introspection about her past, it is scary but ultimately beneficial to her. Not only that, the third game also offers something of a â€“ relatively â€“ happy resolution to the horrific events that a character called Alyssa went through during the first game too.

On the other hand, the second game begins with the happier parts of main character James Sunderlandâ€™s life being nothing more than fading memories. He has also deliberately repressed other memories of his past too. He revisits a place that he once had good times in, but finds it to be cold and empty. Virtually everyone he meets there is creepy, suspicious and/or tragic in some way or another. The one friendly character he meets â€“ Maria â€“ later turns out to actually be there to torment him. Even James himself is someone who you will probably end up liking a lot less as the game progresses and you learn more about him. Itâ€™s a bleak, cynical game with little to no emotional warmth or likeable characters.

The main character of the fourth game isâ€¦ boring. We learn virtually nothing about his backstory and he barely even has a personality. Although he meets a likeable character, his neighbour Eileen, horrible stuff happens to her during at least one or two parts of the game. Tragic ghosts haunt many levels of the game. Not only that, the bulk of this gameâ€™s characterisation is actually focused on the creepy serial killer villain rather than the main characters too. Again, thereâ€™s relatively little in the way of emotional warmth in this game.

So, yes, the second and fourth â€œSilent Hillâ€ games are the scariest games in the series because they tell small-scale mostly self-contained stories with a slightly more â€œrealisticâ€ type of horror and little to nothing in the way of emotional warmth to reassure the player. Again, I personally prefer the atmosphere and style of the first and third â€œSilent Hillâ€ games â€“ but the other two classic games in the series are the scariest.

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

Anyway, I hope that this was interesting ğŸ™‚

Well, for this article in my series about horror videogames, I thought that Iâ€™d compare the accompanying characters in â€œSilent Hill 2â€ (2001) and â€œSilent Hill 4â€ (2004).

Both games feature segments where the main character (James in â€œSilent Hill 2â€ and Henry in â€œSilent Hill 4â€) is accompanied by another character (Maria in â€œSilent Hill 2â€ and Eileen in â€œSilent Hill 4â€) for part of the game.

Yet, despite these superficial similarities, the two games handle this in completely opposite ways. But I should give a SPOILER warning for both games before I go any further.

In fact, I had almost forgotten that Maria accompanies James for parts of â€œSilent Hill 2â€ because it happens for narrative reasons and has little effect on the minute-to-minute gameplay. Yes, Maria will occasionally lag behind James and get out of breath if you run for too long. Maria can also appear to take damage from monsters too â€“ although only if she accidentally happens to be standing in between James and the monster, since the monsters are more interested in James. Plus, if you run on ahead and enter a room, Maria will also teleport there pretty much instantly.

Although Maria originally makes a comment about not wanting to be left alone, the gameplay is structured in a way that James doesnâ€™t really have to protect her. He might feel like he does â€“ and she can also get angry at him if he doesnâ€™t visit her during one part of the game â€“ but, if you know the gameâ€™s story, then the fact that she isnâ€™t really in any serious danger makes perfect sense. Yes, she appears to die at one point in the game but she then shows up completely unharmed later because she â€“ probably â€“ isnâ€™t an ordinary person. She is a supernatural/psychological manifestation of the haunted town of Silent Hill, a distorted reflection of Jamesâ€™ late wife Mary â€“ who is implied to be the type of person James secretly wanted Mary to be.

Yet, if you play the â€œBorn From A Wishâ€ bonus game included with some editions of â€œSilent Hill 2â€, it is strongly implied that Maria both didnâ€™t exist before James arrived in town yet also exists independently of him too. She meets a ghost in an old house, and there is some ambiguity over whether she is similar to this ghost. This bonus game also begins with a creepy scene where she expresses some fairly bleak emotions when she is alone. Still, the ambiguity about Mariaâ€™s humanity and her motivations certainly adds an extra note of unsettling horror to the game.

She accompanies James for part of the game purely for narrative reasons. As such, there are few to none of the traditional gameplay mechanics that youâ€™d expect from this sort of segment, since Maria doesnâ€™t need protecting. Yet, most players will probably be tricked into acting in a protective way thanks to prior experience with protecting accompanying characters in other games. Itâ€™s one of the many subtle ways that â€œSilent Hill 2â€ messes with the playerâ€™s mind.

On the other hand, the accompanied segment of â€œSilent Hill 4â€ (2004) is not only considerably longer â€“ taking up almost half of the game â€“ but it is very much there for gameplay reasons. Although Eileen plays a role in the gameâ€™s story, she isnâ€™t really a major part of it because the story is much more heavily focused on a serial killer called Walter Sullivan.

Instead, Eileen is primarily there for gameplay reasons. The entire style and pacing of the gameplay changes when Eileen shows up. Due to injuries sustained earlier in the game, she cannot climb ladders â€“ forcing the player to find alternate routes around familiar areas, whilst also adding suspenseful vulnerability to her character too.
